Federal Court
Phelan, J.
April 4, 2011.
Counsel:
Randal Montgomery, for the applicant;
Bradley Bechard, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Randal Montgomery, Whitby, Ontario, for the applicant;
Myles J. Kirvan, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Toronto, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.
I.
INTRODUCTION

[1]
Phelan, J.
: The Applicant seeks to overturn an adverse decision by the Immigration and Refugee Board (Board) which was based entirely on her lack of credibility.
II.
FACTUAL BACKGROUND

[2]
Ms. Huseynova is a 67 year old woman who was born in Russia but moved to Azerbaijan and became a citizen when the Soviet Union disintegrated. Her husband died in 1998 and her son moved to Canada in 2005.

[3]
The Applicant claimed that she had volunteered with a human rights organization which was engaged in collecting information about the abuse suffered by soldiers in the Azerbaijani army. She claims that she was subjected to threatening phone calls, police arrest and other acts of intimidation. She fled after she was assaulted by two women and told to cease her volunteer work.

[4]
The Board rejected the Applicant's claim because of serious credibility concerns. There were three adverse credibility findings and one implausible conclusion. The Board commenced its reasons by committing an error in describing the Applicant as a Russian citizen with a Russian passport.

[5]
The Board did not accept the Applicant's explanation for her not having a membership card in the human rights organization, found her explanation of joining the organization inconsistent, and concluded that her explanation for using different names for the organization as nonsensical. The Board concluded that the Applicant was "seriously lacking in credibility" and denied her refugee and protection claim.
III.
ANALYSIS

[6]
It is well established law that credibility and plausibility determinations are factual in nature. The applicable standard of review is reasonableness (
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ). It is equally well established that considerable deference is owed to the Board by virtue of its special position as a trier of fact combined with its area of expertise (
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ).

[7]
The Board's error that the Applicant is Russian is concerning to the Court but not fatal to the reasonableness of the decision. When one reads the decision as a whole, it is apparent that the Board understood the Applicant's nationality and assessed her situation based upon her Azerbaijan citizenship and her situation in that country. Therefore, the error is immaterial.

[8]
There is no basis for the Applicant's allegation of bias or reasonable apprehension of bias. A review of the transcript establishes no basis for this contention.

[9]
The Board's concern about the Applicant's seeming inability to keep the name of her organization straight is not microscopic. It is the very type of evidence which can and does go to credibility.

[10]
The Applicant suggests that the confusion in this area of testimony resulted from problems with the translation of the nuances of language. If the Applicant wished to seriously make that claim, she ought to have produced evidence. If, for some reason, certain words are nuanced and may lead to different choices of words by the translator or words and concepts not readily translatable into English, then the proper way to proceed is by way of expert or at least knowledgeable evidence of this linguistic/translation issue. There was no such evidence here.

[11]
A fair reading of the transcript disclosed that there was an evidentiary basis for the Board's credibility/plausibility conclusion. While not everyone would necessarily reach the same conclusion, particularly those who do not have the opportunity to observe the witness (as the Board did), the very essence of deference is that the Court will not substitute its view of the evidence or apply its own weight to the testimony where there is a reasonably based Board's conclusion. That is the situation in this case.

[12]
There is no basis for the Court's intervention.
IV.
CONCLUSION

[13]
This judicial review will be dismissed. There is no question for certification.
JUDGMENT

[14]
THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that
the application for judicial review is dismissed.
[End of document]

legal_issues: The standard of review applicable to factual findings made by an administrative tribunal.
The materiality of an error made by an administrative tribunal regarding a claimant's nationality.
The sufficiency of evidence required to support an administrative tribunal's adverse credibility determination.
The availability of judicial intervention based on allegations of bias or apprehension of bias.
The requirement for supporting evidence when alleging issues with translation affecting testimony.
The scope of deference owed to an administrative tribunal as a fact-finder with specialized expertise.
The grounds for judicial review of an administrative decision based on credibility assessments.
factual_background: An individual, born in Russia and later becoming a citizen of Azerbaijan, applied for refugee and protection status in Canada.
The applicant’s son immigrated to Canada in 2005.
The applicant claimed to have volunteered with a human rights organization documenting abuse within the Azerbaijani army.
The applicant alleged she experienced threats, arrest, intimidation, and physical assault due to her volunteer work.
The applicant stated she fled Azerbaijan following an assault and a demand to stop her volunteer activities.
The Immigration and Refugee Board (Board) rejected the applicant’s claim due to credibility concerns.
The Board identified inconsistencies in the applicant’s explanations regarding her involvement with the human rights organization, including the organization’s name and her membership status.
The Board initially misidentified the applicant’s citizenship as Russian.

Applicants: The Immigration and Refugee Board’s decision was based entirely on a lack of credibility.
The Board erred in describing the Applicant as a Russian citizen.
The Board’s concern regarding inconsistencies in the name of the human rights organization was unwarranted and stemmed from translation issues.
There was no basis for the Board's adverse credibility findings.
There was no basis for the Board's implausible conclusion.
Respondents: The Board’s determination of credibility and plausibility is a factual matter deserving of deference.
The error regarding the Applicant’s citizenship was immaterial as the Board understood her actual nationality and situation.
There was no allegation of bias or reasonable apprehension of bias.
The Applicant’s inconsistencies regarding the name of the organization were relevant to credibility.
The Applicant failed to provide evidence to support claims that translation issues caused confusion in her testimony.
There was an evidentiary basis for the Board’s credibility and plausibility conclusions.

court_analysis: The court affirmed the Immigration and Refugee Board’s (Board) decision denying the applicant’s claim, finding the decision was reasonable and deserving of deference.

The court acknowledged the Board’s initial error in stating the applicant’s citizenship as Russian instead of Azerbaijani, but determined this error was immaterial as the Board demonstrated understanding of her actual citizenship and assessed her claim accordingly.
The court rejected the claim of bias or reasonable apprehension of bias, finding no evidence to support it in the transcript.

The court upheld the Board’s credibility assessment, finding the applicant’s inconsistent use of names for the human rights organization was a legitimate concern impacting credibility, and that the applicant failed to provide evidence to explain these inconsistencies through translation issues.
The court emphasized that credibility and plausibility determinations are factual and subject to a reasonableness standard of review, requiring deference to the Board’s expertise as a trier of fact.

The court clarified that while another observer might reach a different conclusion, the court’s role is not to substitute its own assessment of the evidence but to determine if the Board’s conclusion was reasonably based, which it found to be the case.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed.
There is no question for certification.
